GAX copy is no. 43, with extra suite of plates.
Acquired with matching funds provided by Stanley J. Seeger '52.

label: "Beset Abroad by Japs - at Home, by Yaps!"
Set of chromolithography albums
description: Three folio albums assembled by the firm at, or close to, the time the specimens were printed. Together they contain approximately 250 leaves with hundreds of mounted specimens and proofs that range in size from full-page folio book illustrations to samples as small as playing cards and labels. The volumes preserve specimens from the first eight years of chromolithography from the presses in Mulhouse and Paris by the inventor Godefroy Engelmann and his successors.
V. I contains [196] p.; v.II contains [146] p. ; v. III contains [160] p.
Specimens printed by Jean Engelmann (from 1842 Engelmann & Graf).

label: Legend of Phra Malai
The Legend of Phra Malai
description: A mid-nineteenth century illustrated folding funeral book, or book of merit, containing a collection of Buddhist texts in the Pali and Thai languages, including the legend of Phra Malai. The manuscript is accordion-folded, written on heavy paper (probably made from mulberry bark), comprising 48 leaves (the final few leaves blank). The manuscript is penned in a single hand in Khmer script and completed on both recto and verso, with eight pairs of watercolor illustrations, a number extensively embellished with gilt, and one fully illustrated double-page panel depicting scenes in Hell, totalling seventeen illustrations.
Phra Malai, or Māleyya, a Buddhist saint, was believed to have lived in Aruradhapura, Sri Lanka, during the reign of the legendary Sinhalese King Duṭṭhagāmaṇi (101-77 B.C.).

label: Dr. Simpson Richmond Yorkshire
description: Medium: Pencil drawings, Pen-and-wash drawings on laid paper
Depiction: Fat man in chair drinks from jug.
Inscribed in pencil, upper left: "Drinking water is [illegible] for a fever".

Richardson's parents lived in Richmond in the 1760's and his brother and sister were born there (See Payne & Payne 2010 p 11 and he made at least one visit in the 1780s (op cit p 100). The title on this small sketch may provide a clue to a lower righter drawing.

label: [The sailor saved].
description: Medium: Pencil drawings, Pen-and-wash drawings on wove paper
Depiction: At sea, men in sailboat rescue sailor from broken mast.

Drawing in reverse for the middle etching on plate 12 of The World in Miniature, forty pages of small vignettes and etchings published in parts by Rudolph Ackermann in 1816 and then reissued as a book in 1817. Copy at Princeton e.g. see <PNC Rowlandson.

Depiction: Boxers with trainers on left and right, brawling crowd in background.
Inscribed in ink, lower left: "Who first shake hands before they box // then give each other playing knocks // With all the kindness of a brother".

Title & inscription in TR's hand. There are a number of other prints and drawings by Rowlandon depicting prize fights, with simialr compostion of contestants in a ring with spectators, but none that I know correspond closely to his one.

label: A grave subject or meditations among the tombs
description: Medium: Pencil drawings, Pen-and-wash drawings on wove paper

Depiction: On left, gravedigger in open grave with spade and skull, mattock beside grave, old man at grave's edge, churchyard with young woman, young man, priest. Verso: Pen sketch of various figures.

'Title above in TR's hand. Also c1800-1810. The same title, an allusion to James Hervey's popular Meditations Among the Tombs (1754) can also be found in Doctor Syntax, Meditating on the Tombstones, plate 10 in Doctor Syntax's Tour in search of the.

label: The high mettled racer [as a cart horse].
description: Item description: From a series of prints, four of which are as follows: "The High Mettled Racer" as a Race Horse. See the Course thronged with Gazers, the Sports are begun, The confusion, but hear, I bet you Sir, done, done. Ten thousand strange murmurs.

"The High Mettled Racer as a Hunter". Now Reynard's turn'd out and o'er hedge and ditch rush 'Dogs, Horses and Huntsmen, all hard at his Brush, Through Marsh, hedge and brier, led by their sly prey, They by scent and by view, cheat a long tedious day, Whi.

"The High Mettled Racer" as a Hack Horse. Grown aged, used up and turn'd out of the stud, Lame, spavin'd and windgalled, but yet with some blood, While knowing postillions his pedigree trace, Tell his Dam won this sweepstakes, his Sire that race, And what.

"The High Mettled Racer" as a Cart Horse. Till at last having labour'd, drudg'd early and late, Bow'd down by degrees, he bends on to his fate, Blind, old, lean and feeble, he tugs 'round a mill, Or draws sand, till the sand of his hour glass stands still.
Signed in plate, lower left: "T. Rowlandson fecit".
Signed in plate, lower right: "J. Hassell aquatinta".

description: Medium: Pencil drawings, Pen-and-wash drawings on wove paper
Depiction: View of rural cottage, nine little children on left, old woman, girl on right, yard with dog, cat, pigs, chickens.

This is unfinished sketch reveals clearly Rowlandson's working method: the pencil underdrawing and the inking in and addition of wash. The theme and figure of man shaving can be compared with the much earlier Domestic Shaving <BMSat 7086> of 1786 .

label: [Swing].
description: Medium: Pencil drawings, Pen drawings on wove paper
Depiction: Yard, woman in rope swing, other figures.

Lively and economic sketch that looks like it has been done from life, possibly in a London pleasure garden such as Vaux-hall; note the box with balcony on the right. Swing scenes can of course be found in Fragonard and pre-revolutionary French artists.

I don't think his is a 'Dissection room' ; rather it is a cabinet of curiosities of a collector or virtuoso with mummies and classical vases as well as skeletons and anatomical specimens, as in The Chamber of Taste in the Royal Collection <RCIN 81088> o.

label: [Domestic scene].
description: Medium: Pencil drawings, Pen drawings on wove paper
Depiction: Interior genre scene. Room with women, children, on right a man shaves.
Interesting because it is unfinished - the key elements of TR's technique - pencil underdrawing, pen lines, wash are present and very efficiently capture the scene.

Title above, inscription below, both in TR's hand. Brilliantly animated pen sketch ca. 1805 using a fine nib - Rowlandson captures the attitudes of all three figures with economy and wit. Probably an idea for a 'Miseries of Human Life' series print neve.

pencil of nature / by H. Fox Talbot
The pencil of nature / by H. Fox Talbot
description: "The first publication of photographs conjoined to a printed text"--Goldschmidt & Naef.
The plates are mounted photographs (calotypes) by Talbot, printed at the Reading Establishment under the supervision of N. Henneman and, later, B. Cowderoy.
The prints are mounted on stiff card, within a single rule inked border, and numbered in the lower right in ink or pencil.

Plates 1 and 5 exist in 2 different images. Plate 1: in earlier copies, the building is cropped; in later copies, the building is fully visible. Plate 5: in earlier copies, the bust faces straight ahead and the print measures 12.5 x 13.5 cm.; in later copies, the bust faces to the left and the print measures 17.5 x 17 cm.
GAX copy: NOTICE: Access to this volume is restricted. Inquire in Graphic Arts Division.
GAX copy has plate 1 with building cropped and plate 2 with bust facing straight ahead.
Title printed in red and black within border of type ornaments.
A 3-line slip, "Notice to the Reader", was inserted in most or all copies of pt. 2; a 5-line slip was inserted in pts. 3-6 and later issues of pt. 1.

Each pt. was issued in cream paper covers, with decorated front cover lithographed in black and red; the pts. were numbered in ms. The front cover was retouched as pt. 5 was being issued: some copies of pt. 5, pt. 6, and later copies of pt. 1 have the cover in second state.
GAX copy bound in contemporary calf by James Hayday; housed in light brown buckram clamshell box.
"Brief historical sketch of the invention of the art": pt. 1, p. [7]-[27].
GAX copy has bookplate of William Twopeny.
GAX copy has stamp on t.p.: Camera Club Library, catalogued & indexed 1930 by Hal. D. Bernstein, librarian.

NOTICE: Because these photographs fade irreversibly in light, access to this volume is restricted. Less sensitive facsimiles are available under same author and title. Inquire in Graphic Arts Division.

A little pretty pocket-book : intended for the instruction of amusement of little Master Tommy, and pretty Miss Polly. With two letters from Jack the Giant-Killer : as also a ball and pincushion : the use of which will infallibly make Tommy a good boy, and Polly a good girl : To which is added, A little song-book, being a new attempt to teach children the use of the English alphabet, by way of diversion.
description: A reprint of Newbery's ed., originally published in London in 1744; title first published in USA by Hugh Gaine in 1762 as "A Little Pretty Book" (cf. Hamilton).
"Rules for behaviour in children" on p. [94]-122.
Includes woodcut and poem about baseball ("base-ball") on p. 43 (the first such mention, according to Hamilton).
Illustrations: Woodcut frontis., captioned "Instruction with Delight," on front pastedown, with 64 small woodcuts at the head of most selections; woodcut and printer's device tailpieces.

Photography album documenting the Morant Bay Rebellion in Jamaica (1865), the Indian Northwest Frontier Hazara Campaign (1867-1870), views of Malta, Ireland, Guernsey, Spain, and elsewhere compiled by Alexander Dudgeon Gulland
description: Compiled by a British Army officer, attributed to be Alexander Dudgeon Gulland, MD.
One hundred and sixty-five albumen photographs (50 Jamaica; 32 India; 64 Malta, Ireland, Guernsey, Spain, and elsewhere).

Photographers whose work is identified: 8 photographs by Samuel Bourne; 5 by Giorgio Sommer; 3 by William Lawrence; several by Francis Frith; and some Jamaica prints attributed to Adolphe Duperly (Jamaica photographs taken before the Morant Bay Rebellion may have been taken by Duperly, or by his studio, A. Duperly and Sons; Jamaica photographs taken after the Rebellion may have been taken by Duperly Brothers, if dated to 1865).
People photographed include: Governor Eyre, George William Gordon, Colonel Fyfe, and Alexander Dudgeon Gulland.

label: Antillas letradas / Antonio Martorell
Las Antillas letradas / Antonio Martorell
description: Portfolio with loose leaves of prints, by Martorell.

This map of the Caribbean is composed of digital prints based on a map of the nineteenth century, the selected texts in their original languages of Spanish, English and French in addition to woodcut in letters of the alphabet with names and faces of the learned authors. Printing began in 2014 on Okawara paper in a Hewlett-Packard printer at El Taller de la Playa, Ponce, Puerto Rico with the help of Milton Ramirez. The edition consists of 100 copies signed and numbered by Antonio Martorell--Colophon.

label: Veües des plus beaux lieux de France et d'Italie
description: A nonce collection made up of plates from the so-called Perelle album. Some plates are before letters with captions written in ink by a contemporary hand. Some plates as issued with lettering. The leaves a numbered in contemporary ink 3 to 285. Some leaves are blank.
Plates by Gabriel, Adam and Nicolas Perelle, as well as Israël Silvestre, and Jacobus van Merlen.

label: Description de la grotte de Versailles
description: Princeton copy 1: Text is preceded by 26 double or folded plates and 56 single plates, variously dated in 1670s and 1680s. Engravers include Silvestre, Le Pautre, I.B. Nolin, Lud. de Chastillon, L. Simonneau le Jeune, Gir. Audran, G. and Io. Edelinck.

label: Sells Brothers Enormous United Shows. Ponderous Elephant and Camel Races Ridden of Natives of East India
grand escalier de Versailles
Le grand escalier de Versailles
description: The signatures of the engravers are present in the print depicting the side portion of the ceiling with the pedestal or tripod of Apollo and the muses Clio and Melpomene: "Step. Baudet sc." and "C. Berey scrip".

SAX copy: Bound with 15 plates, also double-leaf. The first depicts the Escalier des Ambassadeurs at Versailles. Others show the vault of the Galerie du petit apparetement du Roy, the coupola of the chapel of Sceaux, and the coupola of Val-de-Grâce. Two are dated 1681. A number were engraved and/or sold by Audran. Some paintings were by Mignard.

Gluck; trouvant qu'Orphee et Eurydice ont pris de singulieres manieres pendant leur sejour, Passage Choiseul // [Gluck finds that Orpheus and Eurydice have adopted some strange behaviors during their stay at Passage Choiseul].
Dis-donc, Amanda, voila un Espagnol qui te lorgne joliment! // [I say, Amanda, that Spaniard is eyeing you up!].
Mon ami, jamais de la vie ils ne feront du vin blanc avec ces pieds la! // [My friend, never in their lives will they manage to make white wine with feet like those!].

Le Mercredi des Cendres (au matin). Dis-donc, mon vieux, faut nous lever! Voici la femme de menage qui vient faire notre lit! // [The morning of Ash Wednesday. I say, my old man, we must get up! Here is the maid, come to make our bed!].
Ma chere amie, je n'ai pas le temps de m'occuper de vous dans ce moment-ci! // [My dear friend, I simply lack the time to take care of you at the moment!].
Le financier Castorine finira par tuer la presse // [Castorine the banker will finish by killing the Press].

Le prepose au peage du SUND allant rejoindre son ancien collegue d'infortune l'invalide du pond des arts // [The Sund toll-collector visits his old colleague in misfortune, the cripple of the Pont des Arts].

Diable, Diable! J'ai trop presume de mes forces. Je commence a reconnaitre que je ne pourrai plus aller bien loin avec ces deux gaillards-la sur les bras! // [Hell, hell! I expected too much of my forces. Now I begin to see that I can't go much farther wi.
Vous ne lui mettez pas une museliere? Oh no! c'ete inioutile! Il n'avait plous de dents! // [You don't put a muzzle on him? Oh no! It would be useless, as he has no more teeth!].

label: Cheval de 4.
Le Cheval de 4.
description: Issued in 4 fascicles. Each has a separate title: [no. 1] "Le Cheval de 4" ("tirage limité à 26 ex. hors commerce et 6 ex. de luxe") ; [no. 2] "Dédal-e" ("Tirage limité à 28 ex. hors commerce et 3 ex. de luxe") ; [no. 3] "Huit poèmes pour Cécile / Noël Arnaud" (tiré à 150 ex. environ dont 35 de luxe) ; [no. 4] "Expédition Tapié" (tiré à 27 ex.).

Text and illustrations by Michel Tapié, Aline Gagnaire, Jean Jausion, Henri Bernard, Adrienne Peyrot, Noël Arnaud, Simone Bry, Jean Marembert, Loys Masson, and André Poujet, who were members of a collective of Dada artists, the Club des Réverbères.
GAX copy: Fascicles [1] and [2] only. Each has a unique double-page color supplement, missing from other known copies.
GAX copy: No. [1] (Cheval de 4) is copy no. 19.

label: P-Pry's address to the public.

Inscribed in plate: "The Public is most respectfully inform'd in consequence of the number of pirated copies selling with the signature P. Pry, the Artist will for the future insert his real name, William Heath, to all his caricatures & that Thomas McLean.
Signed in plate, lower left: "William Heath late P-Pry".

Keiley, July 1899-July 1902; Dallet Fuguet, July 1899-July 1902; John Francis Strauss, July 1900-July 1902; William F. Hapgood, July 1899- January 1902; Charles W. Stevens, July 1900-April 1902; Juan C. Abel, April-July 1902.

label: Illustrations for T.H. White, The once and future king [5 unpublished prints].
[Boxers of San Francisco] [graphic].
description: Album of tipped in gelatin silver photographs, depicting double image bust portraits (full-face and profile).
The subjects are boxers who fought in the San Francisco area, from the end of World War I to the beginning of the 1930's.
Each photograph is numbered in the negative from A1 to A1093 (a few photographs have been removed).
Nine typescript sheets laid in, numbered A1-A1000 with the names of 294 boxers corresponding to their numbered photographs; with pencil and ink notations.
Periodical issue laid in: Official Boxing Report, Vol.1, No. 1, San Francisco, January 28, 1974.

label: Le jardin des supplices / Octave Mirbeau ; vingt compositions originales de Auguste Rodin
description: "Achevé d'imprimer le 24 mai 1902 ... sur les presses de Philippe Renouard ... Toutes les planches ont été imprimées par Clot et effacées après le tirage"--Colophon.
Includes 20 original lithographs by Auguste Rodin signed in the plate.
Each plate within tissue folder containing descriptive letterpress and reduced outline drawing of the plate.

"Justification du tirage. Deux cents exemplaires numérotés. 1 à 15. -- Quinze exemplaires sur japon impérial avec une double suite des planches de trait. 16 à 45. -- Trente exemplaires sur chine d'origine avec une double suite des planches de trait. 46 à 200. -- Cent cinquante-cinq exemplaires sur vélin fabriqué spécialement par Masure et Perrigot, avec le filigrane Le jardin des supplices"--Page facing title page.

label: Throwing the stocking.
description: Depiction: Caricature; political cartoon. Allegorical scene. Charlotte Augusta lies in bed while the four princesses toss a stocking in her chamber; Queen Charlotte blocks the chamber door to prevent George IV and Leopold from entering the room.

label: The patriot puzzled - or the trusty Scot producing his vouchers.
description: Depiction: Scotsman lifts cloak, revealing Lady Oxford and her illegitimate son to Burdette.

label: The Burdettites hoax'd or one fool makes many.
description: Depiction: Caricature; political cartoon. Hangar and others preparing to escort Burdette upon his release from the Tower, however, Burdette slips away.

label: The cabinet dinner or a political meeting - an illustrious way of enjoying a friend.
description: Depiction: Caricature; political cartoon. Allegorical scene. George IV and members of the "cabinet" he formed before his regency, seated around dining table, sleeping in their chairs. Carlo, the acting dog, sleeps beneath the table.

label: The Union Club masquerade.
description: Depiction; political satire. Union Club Masquerade upon the Treaty of Amiens. George IV as Henry VIII; Maria Fitzherbert as Anne Boleyn; Pitt as Fame.

label: The York sparring match, being M.A. Clarke's, first set to, & who is likely to become the champion of all England.
description: Depiction: Caricature; political cartoon. Allegorical scene. Mary Anne Clarke in House of Commons, wielding sword and striking members.

label: Teresa Guiccioli.
description: Depiction: Bust portrait of Guiccioli, gazing right.
Item description: Mounted on verso of "The double dealers - two strings to your bow - or - who's the dupe".
Signed in plate, lower left: "Drawn by W. Brockedon, 1833".
Signed in plate, lower right: "Engraved by H.T. Ryall".

label: The father's darling.
description: Depiction: Caricature regarding families. Father lovingly indulges young daughter's mischief, mother is upset.
Campus holdings: Another copy in R1807.51F (with scrapbooks), different state.
Signed in plate, lower left: "CW del et sculpt.".

label: The brazen image erected on a pedestal wrought by himself.
description: Depiction: Caricature; political cartoon. Allegorical scene. John Bull, Hibernia, Fox and Sheridan gaze at statue of Pitt; the pedestal of the statue is inscribed with various references to taxation.

label: The Yorshire jockey - or the material of a fox-hunters head.
description: Depiction: Caricature; occupation-related scene. Horse dealer and customer discussing a sale.
Signed in plate, lower left: "Williams scupt.".

label: The school for scandal.
description: Depiction: Caricature; political cartoon. Full-length caricatures of Sheridan and Northumberland at the Westminster election.

label: The comforts of a modern gala.
description: Depiction: Caricature; party scene. Butler standing at mansion entrance, turning away crowd gathered outside due to overcrowding inside.
Signed in plate, lower left: "Woodward delt.".

label: The fall of the modern Wolsey.
description: Depiction: Caricature; political cartoon. Allegorical scene. A Broken Melville seeks refuge in Scottish church.

label: Reasonable charges or ducks metamorphosed! [copy 1].
description: Depiction: Caricature; tavern scene. Two men astonished by the price of their meals.
Signed in plate, lower left: "Woodward del.".

label: The danger of Crim Con!.
description: Depiction: Caricature; adultery scene. Woman trying to seduce another man while her husband is on a long journey.
Signed in plate, lower left: "Woodward delin.".

label: Reasonable charges or ducks metamorphosed! [copy 2].
description: Depiction: Caricature; tavern scene. Two men astonished by the price of their meals.
Signed in plate, lower left: "Woodward del.".

label: A new phantasmagoria for John Bull!!.
description: Depiction: Caricature; political cartoon. Allegorical scene. John Bull seated on a rock at sea, watching an image of Napoleon projected from a magic lantern on shore.
Signed in plate, lower right: "Woodward delt.".

label: A long headed election [copy 1].
description: Depiction: Caricature; political cartoon. Allegorical scene. Group of figures with lower righte heads, discussing current election.
Signed in plate, lower left: "Woodward del.".

label: Leonora.
description: Depiction: Caricature portrait. Woman holding goose on her hand.
Signed in plate, lower left: "Woodward delt."

label: Setting out in life.
description: Depiction: Caricature regarding families. Father and son seated on wooden chairs, conversing about the son's future.
Signed in plate, lower left: "Woodward del.".

label: The road to London or the countryman and the Quakers!.
description: Depiction: Caricature regarding travel. Traveler asks two Quakers for directions.
Signed in plate, lower left: "Woodward delin't.".

label: Napoleon's apotheosis anticipated or the wise men of Leipsic sending Boney to heaven before his time!!!.
description: Depiction: Caricature; political cartoon. Allegorical scene. Wise men of Leipzig watch Napoleon struggle as he is lifted to heaven.
Signed in plate, lower left: "Woodward del.".
Signed with blind stamp, lower right: Encircled bee.

label: A cure for a smoky chimney.
description: Depiction: Caricature; occupation-related scene. Chimney sweep endures complaints from female client.
Signed in plate, lower left: "Woodward del.".

label: The rider and sand-boy.
description: Depiction: Caricature; interior scene. Sand-boy enters a room at an inn to address four seated men.
Item description: Broadside with image and text.
Signed in plate, lower left: "Woodward delt.".

label: The Yorkshire bumkins mistake.
description: Depiction: Caricature regarding domestic life. Male domestic addresses caller at residential entrance.
Signed in plate, lower left: "Woodward del.".

label: Irish binding for the Caricature Magazine.
description: Depiction: Caricature; occupational scene. Bookshop owner and patron in conversation, 'Ah--Ah--Master Pat, so you have got my friend Teggs Caricature Magazine I see, and you say you want to have it handsomely bound,--suppose you have it done in Russia.' /.
Signed in plate, lower left: "Woodward del."

label: First going alone.
description: Depiction: Caricature regarding motherhood. Mother exclaiming proudly as toddler takes first steps.
Signed in plate, lower left: "Woodward delt."

label: [Shipboard scene with seasick passengers].
description: Depiction: Caricature regarding transportation. Seasick passengers.

label: A long headed election [copy 2].
description: Depiction: Caricature; political cartoon. Allegorical scene. Group of figures with lower righte heads, discussing current election.
Signed in plate, lower left: "Woodward del.".

label: A Parliamentary debate in Pipes's Ground.
description: Depiction: Caricature; political cartoon. Duel between Walpole and Chetwynd.

label: A political fair.
description: Depiction: Caricature; political cartoon. Allegorical scene. Fair grounds with each booth representing a different nation's political issues.

label: Admonition and gratitude.
description: Depiction: Caricature; occupation-related scene. Lawyer admonishing grateful criminal.
Signed in plate, lower left: "Woodward del't.".
Signed in plate, lower left: "W-S sculpt.".

label: The sailors defence!!.
description: Depiction: Caricature; court scene. Sailor appears before magistrate for beating another man.
Item description: Date from Yale University Library.
Signed in plate, lower left: "Woodward del.".

label: One fine morning, or, How they might undo me.
description: Depiction: Caricature portrait. Long serpentine line of well-dressed men, gazing at startled Beerbohm as they pass him by.

label: A court conversation.
description: Depiction: Caricature; political cartoon. Allegorical scene. Room with Anson (as a goose) and Fox (as a fox), watching the burning of Byng in effigy taking place on the street outside their door.

label: A bene-fit. I wish I hadn't bought the tickets!.
description: Depiction: Caricature regarding theater. Lobby of Drury Lane Theater crowded with disappointed patrons who bought pit tickets, but are unable to enter the theater because of overcrowding.

label: A common sergeant late one of the Queen's own.
description: Depiction: Caricature portrait. Full-length view, right profile of Denman carrying enormous legal brief; pencil figure drawings on recto and verso.

label: A king-fisher, and a water-wag-tail.
description: Depiction: Caricature; political cartoon. Lady Conyngham and George IV fishing.

label: A sharp frost. How comfortable pockets are in cold weather.
description: Depiction: Caricature regarding poverty. Impoverished man with hands in ripped coat pockets.

label: A brace of blessings.
description: Depiction: Caricature regarding prosperity. At left, seated lawyer reviews lengthy bill for various services; at right, seated clergyman drinks burgundy and smokes pipe beside table on which lies lengthy bill for food, alcohol, and tobacco.

Depiction, mount verso: Six small pencil drawings [head of dog; half-length portrait of woman; head of horse; bust portrait of man; bust portrait of monk; full-length portrait of woman holding bird] and three small hand-colored prints [fruit spray, lion,.

label: A king-fisher.
description: Depiction: Caricature portrait. Full-length profile of George IV fishing at water's edge.

label: A sketch taken at Newmarket.
description: Depiction: Caricature portrait. Full-length view, right profile of Frederick Augustus, Duke of York and Albany.

label: A deep one, or boots on a new principle.
description: Depiction: Caricature regarding fashion. Young man discusses new boots with his father.

label: A shooting party.
description: Depiction: Caricature regarding country life. One man teaches three others how to shoot a pistol.

label: A pilgrim.
description: Depiction: Caricature; political cartoon. Allegorical scene. Frederick Augustus wearing military uniform and pilgrim's cloak, carrying urn, walking in landscape toward setting sun with face of George III superimposed on it.

label: A privy council laying their heads together, or necessary business.
description: Depiction: Caricature; political cartoon. Allegorical scene. Camden, Pitt, and Thurlow seated on lower righte commode.
Signed in plate, upper left: "Delineated by O'Burke".
Signed in plate, upper right: "Executed by Priapus".

label: A gallant colonel.
description: Depiction: Caricature portrait. Full-length view, right profile of Stanhope riding leery horse.

label: A medley of characters. Ascot Heath races June 1791.
description: Depiction: Caricature regarding recreation. Spectators watch Ascot races from two carriages. Above, two profile bust portraits of men, facing each other.

label: A medley of characters. At a concert.
description: Depiction: Caricature regarding music. Six different concert-goers.

label: A misfit. Mr. Odg-r trying on the boots or Mr. Berkeley.
description: Depiction: Caricature portrait. George Odger trying on enormous shoe of the late Henry Berkeley.
Signed on stone with monogram [fish entwined on letter "L"], lower right.

label: A contest between soot & flour.
description: Depiction: Caricature; street fight between a chimney sweep and a gentleman wearing a powdered wig.

label: A good fellow.
description: Depiction: Caricature; half-length, 3/4 right profile of a drunken man.

label: A scene near Arbroath. Or our Nell taking a dip.
description: Depiction: Caricature regarding obesity. Rotund woman standing on beach, scantily clad.

label: A chip off the old block.
description: Depiction: Caricature; waterfront scene. Father with hand on son's head, sailing ship in background.

label: A recruiting party.
description: Depiction: Caricature; political cartoon. Allegorical scene. Parade of inanimate objects, one carries flag made from newspaper, "Publicans Advertiser".

label: A female review.
description: Depiction: Women of the "Forlorn Hope Battalion" stand in formation as directed by their leader, ". . . In all human probability, the enemy will charge in the rear, I have therefore placed in the front ranks widows, and ladies who have been more than once.
Signed in plate, lower left: "Satira invt.".

label: A courier just setting out. Who has any letters to send?.
description: Depiction: Caricature; political cartoon. Allegorical scene. George III as a courier, riding a donkey which has a man's face; surrounding him are five men, three of whom are handing him letters.
Inscribed in plate, upper right: "Sketch'd from life while his boots were greasing".

label: A regular guy.
description: Depiction: Caricature; occupation-related scene. Policeman bound to wooden chair, holding lantern and [pencils?], gazing out at viewer.

label: A doctor and his friends.
description: Depiction: Caricature regarding alcoholism. Two men drinking with the devil and Death.
Signed in plate, lower left: "A.M.D. sct.".

label: An English sloop engaging a Dutch Man of War.
description: Depiction: Caricature; street scene. Prostitute seducing sailor.

label: Banditti.
description: Depiction: Caricature; political cartoon. George III, Burke, Washington, Sheridan, Keppel and Fox gathered around a table; two other men asleep beneath the table.

label: Bonaparte's last will and testament previous to the invasion!!.
description: Depiction: Caricature; political cartoon. Allegorical scene. Napoleon makes the devil executor of his will.

label: America in flames.
description: Depiction: Caricature; political cartoon. Allegorical scene. America personified as a woman, engulfed in flames fanned by North, Bute, and Mansfield.

label: A sudden call, or one of the corporation, summoned from his favorite amusement.
description: Depiction: Caricature regarding death. Death (as a skeleton) chokes gluttonous, gout-ridden man dining at table.

label: A steam coach with some of the machinery going wrong. Something wrong, my eyes Bob, if our parson ha'nt lost his living.
description: Depiction: Caricature; accident scene. Passengers ejected from exploding steam coach.

label: England's difficulty is Ireland's opportunity.
description: Depiction: Caricature; political cartoon. Allegorical scene. Irishman picks pocket of Englishman restraining Sans-culotte.

label: Absent without leave.
description: Depiction: Caricature portrait. Full-length view, left profile of Ward riding exhausted horse.

label: At a tragedy.
description: Depiction: Caricature; theater scene. Close-up of male theater audience members, crying.

label: A view of the parade at Bath.
description: Depiction: Caricature; outdoor scene. Crowd of figures mingling on the North Parade in Bath.

label: A suit of law fits me better than a suit of cloaths.
description: Depiction: Caricature; political cartoon. Allegorical scene. Full-length view of man standing beside tree, holding document "I'll go to law" in his hand.
Signed in plate, lower left: "Invented & engraved by W.H.".

label: Going to the post.
description: Depiction: Caricature; accident scene. Two men riding horses; one horse crashes into a post, ejecting his rider.

label: A strolling Methodist.
description: Depiction: Caricature regarding religion. John Wesley standing on barrel, fervently preaching, surrounded by crowd.
Inscribed in pencil, on mount, below: "Rev. John Wesley".

label: At a sale of pictures.
description: Depiction: Caricature regarding art auctions. Seated man, holding document.

label: Beauty & innocence, charm'd with the Turkish beggar.
description: Depiction: Caricature; street scene. Mother and son approach a Turkish amputee beggar.

label: Boby Banboo Mama's own darling. When old enough he shall have a commission to frighten away the crows.
description: Depiction: Caricature; military scene. Army officer with enormous hat.

label: Addition.
description: Depiction: Caricature regarding families. Two men discussing how many boys are enough for a family.

label: An ass loaded wth. preferments.
description: Depiction: Caricature; political cartoon. Allegorical scene. William Wake, Archbishop of Canterbury holding a whip and walking behind his son-in-law (a donkey laden with ecclesiastical appointments).

label: A well-fed citizen going to his country seat at Horn-sey.
Anticipation.
description: Depiction: Caricature; political cartoon. Allegorical scene. Fox and North boxing.

label: Bony's visions or a great little man's night comforts.
description: Depiction: Caricature; political cartoon. Allegorical scene. Napoleon leaps from his bed, into a nightmare featuring his new-born son along with demons, goblins, and various political figures.
Signed in plate, lower left: "The Caricaturist General fecit".

description: Depiction: Caricature; political cartoon. Allegorical scene. Williams-Wynne roasting on a spit.

description: Depiction: Caricature; occupation-related scene. Merchant carrying canes and a whip.

label: Fly away pretty moth.
description: Depiction: Caricature; anthropomorphic scene. Three flying insects hover around man with insect head sleeping in chair.

label: Duty.
description: Depiction: Man standing in worn-out postillon boots.

label: Devotion in Dukes Place - or contractors returning thanks for a loan.
description: Depiction: Caricature regarding religion. Synagogue congregation, singing.

label: Giving mouth.

label: Don't pull my nose so hard; curse it you take it for a sow's ear.

label: Buying a German sausage or a foreign dainty for the wedding feast!!.
description: Depiction: Caricature; political cartoon. Allegorical scene. John Bull buys German sausage for the queen.

label: Caryatides of the Garrick Club.
description: Depiction: Caricature portraits. Full-length profiles of two gentlemen standing outdoors, facing each other.

label: Civic celebrities No. 3 [Maurice Brooks].
description: Depiction: Caricature portrait. Full-length view, left profile of Brooks standing with hands in pockets.
Inscribed in plate, lower margin: "One of the most exalted images amongst the Elect; who rises to the supreme height of felicity, only to sink down again; but who Brooks no impediment".

label: Any body buy a wig!!! Has been rather ill used & will go cheap.
description: Depiction: Caricature; political cartoon. Full-length view of man holding wig and robe, gazing out at viewer.

label: Eques Cantab.
description: Depiction: Caricature regarding horsemen. Left profile of a figure on horseback, followed by dog.
Signed in plate, lower right: "H [or M]".

label: Do stop that razor again, by G- I'd as soon be shav'd with a carving knife.
description: Depiction: Caricature; occupation-related scene. Barber shaving rotund client.

label: Country acting - or no tricks upon travellers.
description: Depiction: Caricature regarding theater. Kitchen where actor asks man when he will be done roasting a bird so the jack-spit can be used for his performance.

label: Short tails are all the fashion now except with Freshmen.
description: Depiction: Caricature regarding fashion. Rotund woman holding short tail of man's hair.

label: Fleabites or the psalm singer.
description: Depiction: Caricature; interior scene. Couple lying in bed. Woman sleeps as man moans about flea bites.

label: Drumming out of the regiment!!
description: Depiction: Caricature; political satire. Outdoor scene. Dejected Norfolk led away in procession by Dundas, followed by Pitt (beating drum) and Windham[?] (playing fife); George III observes from window, using telescope; Fox cries in background, standing b.

label: The Times, Pl. 2.
description: Political cartoon regarding the murder of William Allen in 1768.

On label accompanying the print: "A landscape, with the ghost of 'Murdered Allen' rising from the ground in the centre. On the left a column inscribed with the names of Hampden, Marvell, Sidney, and Russell ; Britannia seated at the foot, regarding Pitt, who is standing beneath an angel bearing a crown of laurels, showing Caesar (the king) his 'triumphs.' On the right, another column inscribed with the names of Carr, Buckingham, Laud, and Macclesfield ; just in front of it a zebra, with the head of George III, Lord Bute on his back, and beside him in a pannier, the Princess of Wales, who is acting somewhat indelicately ; above and round them animals, etc., symbolic of corruption. Beneath are 90 lines of verse, objects being occasionally introduced in place of words . . . William Allen was killed by soldiers in a riot outside the King's Bench Prison, where Wilkes was lodged, on May 10th, 1768. An officer and a corporal were subsequently found guilty of willful murder."

Photographed by John Wareham, the illustrations were digitally adapted and made into polymer plates by Gerald Lange. The woodcut was designed and carved by Keiji Shinohara. Paul Shaw provided calligraphy of the Polish lyrics. The typefaces are Guild Samson uncial & Perpetua, printed onto hand-stained Wahon paper. Daniel Kelm provided consultation on the triptych structure; box design & construction is by Franklin Nichols Woodworking"--Colophon.
"Designed, printed & bound by Robin Price in an edition of sixty copies during the spring of 1996"--Colophon.
Issued in slide-top cherry wooden case (34 x 18 cm.)

Astronomicum Cæsareum
description: Author's name given at head of fol. [3] recto (=A3 recto) as: Apianus.
Illustrated title page, with two woodcuts, one a frame surrounding the title, the other circular, with printed text on bottom left and right.
Reference in title is to Emperor Charles V to whom and his brother, King Ferdinand I, this work is dedicated.
Imprint from colophon, printed in reverse (mirror image).
Signatures: A-G⁴(±G2, G3+chi1) H-I⁴ k⁴ L-N⁴ O⁶ (-O6) chi2-chi3 (chi2 verso, chi3 verso blank).

38 full page text illustrations, 22 of them with volvelles (moving discs), many also with centrally attached silk threads. Volvelles are foundon the recto of leaves B3, C1, C3, D1, D3, E1, E2, E4, F2, F3, F4, chi1, G4, k3, k4, L1, L2, L3, L4, M1 and M3 and the verso of leaf G3. Additionally, a large number of smaller text illustrations are present.
"Without doubt ... the most luxurious and intrinsically beautiful scientific book that has ever been produced" -- Derek de Solla Price.

Fol. [60] recto (=chi3 recto) dated: Ratisbona, die vigesima quarta mensis Iulii, Anno Domini millesimo quingentesimo quadragesimo primo [Regensburg, 24 July 1541] and signed: Carolus. This leaf is lacking in many copies.
Cf. Price, D. de S. Science, 1967 p. 104; Gingerich, O. "Early astronomical books with moving parts", AB Bookman's Weekly p. 1507-1508, October 23, 1989.

Text divided into two parts; the second part has two alternative titles: Meteoroscopium planum Apiam (fol. [49] recto = M4 recto) and: Astronomici cæsarei per Petrum Apianum concinnati pars secunda (fol. [49] verso = M4 verso).

label: Courses de testes et de bague faittes par le roy et par les princes et seigneurs de sa cour, en l'année 1662
description: Dedication to the Dauphin on pages [i]-[iv], signed by Perrault.
Engraved title page (showing a bust of Louis XIV overlooking the Place Royale) signed by Rousselet; other engravings by Silvestre and Chauveau.

16 leaves of unnumbered plates (on 4 folded double-leaves) following page 8, depict the procession, and 3 other double-leaf plates (after pages 63-64, 65-66, 67-[68], resp. in second paging sequence) depict the tournament.
Other engravings depict tournament participents, in elaborate chivalric costumes as Romans, Persians, Turks, East Indians, and Native Americans; separate engravings show their emblematic devices.
A few leaves (in the page 17-[62] sequence) also have printing on verso: e.g. 34, 50, 52, 59.
First colophon (p. [68] (1st page sequence): "A Paris: De l'Imprimerie royale, par les soins de Sebastien Mabre-Cramoisy, Directeur de cette Imprimerie. M.DC.LXX."
"Circvs regivs, sive Pompa eqvestris Lvdovici XIV; carmen heroicvm" (by Fléchier) on pages 65-104 at end.
Second colophon (p. 104): "Parisiis, in Typographia Regia, curante Sebastiano Mabre-Cramoisy, eiusdem Typographiae Directore. M.DC.LXX."

The literal sequence of pages and engraved leaves is: 2 unnumbered pages, 1 unnumbered leaf of plates, 4 unnumbered pages, 8 pages, 16 leaves of unnumbered plates (4 folded double-leaves), 17-[62] leaves; 63-64 pages, 1 folded double-leaf of plates, 65-66 pages, 1 folded double-leaf of plates, 67-[68] pages, 1 folded double-leaf of plates, 65-104 pages

label: Album pintoresco de la isla de Cuba
description: First published in Havana in 1847-1848 as Viaje pintoresco alrededor de la isla de Cuba, by Federico Mialhe. It was pirated twice in the next decade by the Berlin publisher Bernardo May, who succeeded in defending himself against a breach of copyrigt suit by Mialhe and his Havana publisher Louis Marquier.
Includes illustrated title page and two maps: Mapa historico pintoresco moderno de la isla de Cuba and Plano pintoresco de la Habana.

Palau 5395 and Le bibliophile americaine / Librairie Ch. Chadenat, no. 20 (1897), both describe editions containing 26 ill. rather than the 27 contained here. Palau dates his ca. 1840; Chadenat, 1853. NUC pre-1956 calls for 2 maps, as does Chadenat.

label: Descrizione del sacro monte della Vernia.
description: Issued without t.p; title from dedication (leaf [1]), which reads: Illmo. et reuerendissmo. patron mio colendissmo. monsignor arciuescouo di Monreale e generale de' Minori osservanti, frate Arcangelo da Messina s. Dismettendo ogni cerimonia ... vengo à dedicarli quest'opera della descrizione del sacro monte della Vernia ... il disegnatore è stato ... sig. Iacopo Ligozio ... Di Fiorenza il dì primo di giugno 1612 ... Fra Lino Moroni di Firenze.
Leaves of text (descriptive letterpress keyed to the plates)--printed on one side only, within type flower borders.

Illustrations: 23 prints from 26 plates : engraving (11), etching and engraving (12) ; full-page (21), image 77 x 41 cm. (1), image 50 x 41 cm. (1). All after Ligozzi. Comprise frontispiece (St. Francis with armorial devices, trophies and emblems of spiritual and temporal power) by Domenico Falcini and 22 views of sites on Mount Verna associated with St. Francis; 7 are signed with monogram RS (Raffaello Schiaminossi), the others being ascribed to Falcini. The Schiaminossi plates are etchings retouched with burin; the Falcini plates are engravings and etchings with engraving. The 2 large views are composed of prints on 3 and 2 conjoined sheets, respectively. There are engraved overlays on plates F, G, I, O and R (with 2). For detailed description, reproduction of plates and transcription of letterpress, cf. Jacopo Ligozzi : le vedute del sacro monte della Verna, i dipinti di Poppi e Bibbiena / a cura di Lucilla Conigliello. 1992. no. 10-32, figs. x-xxxii. For Schiaminossi plates, cf. also: Italian etchers of the Renaissance & baroque / Sue Welsh Reed, Richard Wallace. c1989. no. 109. Illustrated Bartsch, v. 38, p. 152-158, figs. 131-136.
GAX copy: Purchased with funds provided by the Friends of the Princeton University Library.

description: "Entered according to act of Congress, in the year 1853, by James M. Hutchings, in the clerk's office of the U.S. District Court of the Northern District of California. Orders, pre paid, addressed 'Box H, Placerville, El Dorado Co., Cal.'"
Surrounded by eleven wood-engravings, variously signed "Eastman," "H. Eastman, del.," and "Anthony & Baker."

Hutchings' Miner's ten commandments first appeared in the June 2, 1853, issue of the Placerville herald, and was frequently re-published with illustrations, selling as many as 97,000 copies in one year. Cf. Hutchings, J.M. Seeking the elephant, 1849, 1980, p. 22.
Text in three columns on broadside; printed area, including ruled border, measures 27.6 x 22.2 cm.

"L'édition originale des 'Mannequins' a été tiré à 30 exemplaires numérotés de 1 à 30 et 7 exemplaires nominatifs, tous signés par Man Ray. Les épreuves originales des photographies contenues dans l'ouvrage portent au dos le cachet de l'atelier de l'artiste. Les négatifs rayés et le manuscrit ont été joints à l'exemplaire numéro 1. Quelques exemplaires hors commerce ont été réservés aux collaborateurs et amis. Cette édition a été reliée par Mercher en son atelier de la rue Visconti à Paris. Il a utilisé son procédé de relieure à décor photographique exécuté d'après une composition de Man Ray spécialement conçue pour cet ouvrage"--Leaf [8].

label: Collection of 7 prints after Maerten de Vos’ Life and Passion of Christ, one signed as engraved by Johann Bussemacher (fl. 1580-1613), one signed by Johann Christoph Weigel (1654-1726), others all unsigned, but also by Johann Bussemacher.
description: Engraved prints with textiles cut and attached, known as Spickelbilder (‘embroidered prints’) in Germany, after Maerten de Vos depicting the Easter Passion (Vita, passio et resurrectio Jesu Christi). The embellished prints show: Christ in the Garden of Gethsemane, Last Supper (engraved by Weigel), Kiss of Judas and Arrest of Christ, Christ before Pilate, Flagellation of Christ, Nailing on the Cross (engraved by Bussemacher), and Resurrection. Dressed prints became popular in the late 17th century when convents saw them as an additional source of income; the careful cutting out of prints and decorating them with textiles had become a household pastime for women by the early 18th century. All prints with three-line (once one-line) German Bible text at foot.

German inscription: "Seht, wie den ganzen Bau der weit entlegnen Belt; // Des Birckels Fuss bestimmt, der Kugel kaum enthalt, // Der Menschen [wir?] beschreibt, die auf derselben wallen, // Wie muss nicht Gottes Merck im grossen wohlgefallen?".

Latin inscription: "Angustus, radius totum complectitur orbem, // Inque globo parvo maximus orbis adest. // Humanus calamus describit regna, hominesque, // Conditor! O quantum, quod facis ipsus, opus!".

label: [Man smoking a long pipe].
description: Signed in plate, lower right: "Geuder del et sc.".
Inscription below print, first verse: "Um meine Grillen zu verjagen // Greif' nach der Pfeiffe ich geschwind, // Und bas' die Sorgen so mich plagen // Durch Rauchtaback, frisch in den Wind.".
Inscription below print, second verse: "Ich denke dann in meinen Herzen // (Wenn er zur Hohe steigt hinan,) // Ach! So vergehen Freud u. Schmerzen, // Dampf, ist die ganze Lebensbahn.".

Inscription below print, first verse in translation: "To chase away my silly thoughts // I quickly reach for the pipe // And blow away the worries that plague me // In tobacco-smoke, fresh in the wind.".
Inscription below print, second verse, in translation: "I think then, in my heart // (When it climbs up to the heights,) // Oh! Happiness and pain go away together, // Smoke is every part of life.".

Costumes français sous Louis XIV
description: Plates signed by St. Jean, many undated, with others variously dated.
Plates present not-from-life depictions of French nobility, the King, Queen, Dauphin, and men/women "of quality."
Three double-fold plates depict women in varying states of undress preparing for bed or a bath; a fold-out plate shows a mounted "Louis Le Grand commanding his army in with Cambray in the background;
GAX copy: Collection undated; last engraving in Princeton's volume is signed with the date 1696; engraved dates on other plates range from 1683 to 1696.

GAX copy: A collection of 76 engravings, bound together here, showing French nobility, the King, Queen, Dauphin, and men/women "of quality" in various fashions, as well as a few depicting (well-attired) country-people; published variously between 1678 and 1695 by Jean Dieu de Saint-Jean, designer, publisher and print-seller.
GAX copy: Plates are hand-numbered in ink, with some inconsistencies: unnumbered plate between "63" and "64, with last plate (#75 in this sequence) unnumbered and proceded by "74."

GAX Hamilton SS 80 copy imperfect : Correct t.p. for vol. 1 is wanting, replaced with one for v. 2 when the name was changed to Yankee Doodle or Young America; t.p. for v. 2 is wanting. Vol. contains the complete 26 nos., and 5 nos. of Vol. II. Cf. Hamilton.
Contains over 40 illustrations by McLenan, over 50 by Hoppin, over 15 by Howard and some by Goater, Carleton, Frank Bellew, J.H. Manning; wood engraving by T.W. Strong.

label: El río de Martín Pérez y otros poemas / Nancy Morejón ; con diseño y dibujos de Rolando Estévez
description: Mimeographed reproduction of typescript, manuscript titles, drawings, and borders on individual leaves of coarse brown paper and white bond with mounted decorated-paper cutouts. Endpapers include white tissue paper and light brown tracing paper. Stapled, glued to brown paper wrappers, and tied with cord. Front wrapper has a collage of colored and decorated papers, string, cinnamon bark, twigs, and grains of corn. A white paper scroll with mimeographed, illustrated title and wooden ends is tied with a yellow string and hangs from the cord.
Part of a collection of handmade chapbooks, most with cords for hanging (literatura de cordel), published by Ediciones Vigía under the auspices of the Cuban Ministry of Culture.
"Consta de doscientos ejemplares numerados, firmados por su autora ..."--Colophon.

label: History of the monument : with a brief account of the great fire of London, which it commemorates / by Charles Welch
description: GAX copy Includes: 1. 'Another Dreadfull Suicide at the Monument by a Young Woman' (380 x 253 mm), [Printed and published by E. Lloyd, c. 1842] (illustrated broadside); 2. Popular woodcut print (400 x 160 mm), [c. 1810], with contemporary colour, showing man and woman throwing themselves off the Monument; 3. 'Another Suicide by Precipitation from the Monument' [London, 1839], 12mo (140 x 85 mm), pp. 10 with large folding dramatic woodcut (430 x 140 mm) (pamphlet); 4. 'Just published the authentic particulars of the most determined and frightful suicides of a Youth ... also the full account of Miss Moyes, by throwing themselves of the Monument ... London, published by G. Gilbert ... printed by T. Goode ..., [1839], 8vo (178 x 105 mm) (pamphlet); 5. Bound in or kept in the rear pocket are the following printed guide books to the Monument: a) Arnott, Samuel. The column called the Monument, described, erected to perpetuate the dreadful Fire of London in the year 1666 ... London, printed by J. Bryan ... for Samuel Arnott, Keeper of the Monument, [1805]. Large 12mo, pp. 22, including frontispiece woodcut of the Monument; b) Woodward, Thomas. The History of the Monument in London. London, printed for Thomas Woodward, Keeper of the Monument, [1865?]. 12mo. pp. 24, [2], printed on thin paper stock, in the original illustrated yellow wrappers, wrappers with small holes. Two more copies, one undated '1872' edition, and the other undated '1880' edition, both in excellent condition in wrappers. c) Welch, Charles. History of the Monument. Third edition. London, 1898. 12mo (120 x 90 mm), pp. 62, in illustrated white wrappers, in excellent condition.

description: Princeton copy 1 Extra illustrated by the insertion of 78 additional plates from the various works of George Cruikshank.

label: Quincuplex psalterium : Gallicum, Rhomanum, Hebraicum, vetus, conciliatum : pr[a]eponu[n]tur quae subter adijciuntur : epistola, epilogus disputationis psal. xxx, appendix in psal. xxx, prologi Hieronymi tres, partitio psalmorum triplex, indices psalmorum duo
description: Edited with commentary by Jacques Lefèvre d'Étaples.
Edition statement at head of title.

Colophon: Absolutum fuit hoc quincuplicis psalterii opus in coenobio Sancti Germani Prope Muros Parisienses anno a natali Christi Domini 1508, et in clarissimo Parisiorum Gymnasio ex calcotypa Henrici Stephani officina e regione scholaru[m] decretorum ad secundam & castigatiorem emissionem susceptum anno eiusdem Christi Saluatoris omnium 1513 idibus Iunijs. Illi igitur qui absoluere & absolutu[m] in publicum emittere dedit. Laus et gratiarum actio in saecula saeculorum amen.

Presents five Latin versions: three by St. Jerome presented in parallel columns (Gallicum, the text used by churches in Gaul; Rhomanum, that used in Roman churches; Hebraicum, made directly from the Hebrew) and, after, two more in parallel columns (vetus, a text older than the Jerome text, and conciliatum, a corrected version by Lefèvre).
Part of title within ornamental border with vines and angels and initials H.S.
Text, type ornaments and paragraph marks in black and red. Some Hebrew text.
